Description: Fragmentary top of a mould-made pottery lamp with retouched decoration. The filling-hole area is surrounded by a crescent, or pair of horns, with knobbed tips, decorated at the roots with short grooves and an impressed circle. The wide convex shoulder is decorated with incised triangles and lines and impressed circles. On the left side is an ornamental lug in the form of a dolphin. Red-brown Nile silt fabric with abundant mica, organics and white inclusions.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Town (Naukratis), Site 95 (Petrie), the terracotta workshop, at the eastern edge of the town
Curator's comments: Parallel from Herakleopolis Magna (Petrie 1905, pl.59, no. O.44 Royal Ontario Museum 916.I.280), perhaps influenced by Knidian types found in Athens (Howland 1958, Type 40A; Bailey 1975, 260). Fabric is consistent with Nile Delta productions, including Naukratis. Howland, R.H. 1958. The Athenian Agora, IV, Greek lamps and their survivals, Princeton. Petrie, W.M.Fl. 1905, Roman Ehnasya (Herakleopolis Magna), 1904, London.
Bibliographic references: Lamp / Catalogue of the Lamps in the British Museum (Q558)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KD.013) (Phase 1)
